Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Affordable Housing and Equitable Recovery: A Study of the 2013 Colorado Flash Floods

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

This RAPID grant funds the collection of data on housing recovery following the September 2013 flash floods in Colorado. The research results will inform better local, state, and federal disaster management policies and programs aimed at community recovery. The floods were the costliest disaster in Colorado state history, destroying more than 1,500 homes and triggering over $2 billion in economic loss. Low and moderately priced housing was particularly hard-hit, with hundreds of affordable units destroyed. Communities are struggling with decisions about where, when, and if to rebuild housing, while displaced residents are unable to return home because of the loss of affordable housing options. The investigators will collect detailed data on household and community decision-making at this crucial time of the disaster, in order to better understand the issues and challenges facing communities who have lost significant portions of their affordable housing stock.

The fate of affordable housing is central to the character of long-term disaster recovery, however, existing research is unclear on the full range of variables that influence decisions about the reconstruction or replacement of affordable housing post-disaster. To identify these variables and understand how they affect recovery efforts, the research team will collect, analyze and disseminate data on housing recovery in three Colorado communities impacted by the 2013 flash floods. The project team will collect data in two distinct waves. Wave "I" will be a baseline survey of 100-120 households living in affordable housing prior to the disaster. Based on their analysis of the results of this baseline survey, the team will then recruit a sub-sample of respondents to take part in an in-depth interview for Wave "II" of the study. These interviews will allow for a richer understanding of the processes of displacement and how household losses complicate and disrupt daily living and, eventually, longer term recovery. To supplement the household survey and interviews, the team will interview key informants from local, state, and federal government and civil society. The study will provide much-needed insights into the dynamic nature of disaster recovery decision making at the individual and community scale, and will advance our scientific understanding of long-term disaster recovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In September of 2013, a heavy precipitation event led to more than 17 inches of rainfall in the Colorado Front Range region. The resulting floods killed 11 people and caused nearly $3 billion in damage across 17-counties, the costliest disaster in state history. The flood’s impacts were most severe in three counties in the north-central part of the state: Boulder, Larimer and Weld. In those counties, dozens of communities and thousands of households were affected. Households living in affordable housing were especially vulnerable to the floods. Hundreds of affordable housing units were significantly damaged or destroyed in a region where housing affordability is an ongoing challenge.  

The goal of this project was to understand affordable housing in disaster recovery, from the perspective of households who rely on it, and the communities and public officials who decide whether and where affordable housing gets rebuilt. We conducted interviews with 100 flood-affected households (including 30 Spanish speaking households) and 42 public officials or decision makers active in disaster recovery. We also attended hundreds of hours of disaster recovery meetings and events.

The findings from our study—that very little of the affordable housing was or will be rebuilt--indicate that the loss of affordable housing during a disaster, and especially in a fast growing region like the Colorado Front Range, presents unique, long-term challenges for households and communities. For households, the loss of affordable housing often meant displacement from their communities and less ability to participate in recovery decision-making processes. It also meant higher housing costs after the disaster, which placed additional strain on lower-income and socially vulnerable households. For communities, the recovery of affordable housing was a complex and challenging task, due to the web of internal and external resources with different rules, requirements, and timelines, and varying levels of support and demands from the public. Considered together, our findings have contributed valuable case study evidence on the specific challenges of disaster recovery, and provide important insights into the factors that influence uneven recovery at a household, community, and regional scale.

The project also provided substantive educational opportunities for eight graduate research assistants and two undergraduate research assistants, who gained valuable experience in survey research and data analysis and knowledge about disasters and recovery. Work under this grant also contributed to a peer reviewed journal article, a book chapter, and numerous presentations at state and national conferences by both faculty investigators and student research assistants. Findings from the study have been shared with local, state, and federal officials active in disaster recovery, and have informed several post-disaster recovery and resilience planning processes. Project faculty have also incorporated findings from the research into graduate and undergraduate courses on environmental planning and disaster management.
